fr_reason: The competitor patent's functional purpose reduces carbon dioxide emissions, which is a more pressing environmental concern compared to improving efficiency in molten carbonate fuel cells.
fr_ours: Improves efficiency of molten carbonate fuel cells by recycling excess hydrogen from the anode exhaust for reuse, enabling higher utilization beyond the traditional 70% to 75%.
fr_competitor: Reduces carbon dioxide emissions in hydrocarbon cracking systems during olefin production by converting methane into electricity in a fuel cell.
tu_reason: Both patents demonstrate unique technical solutions. Our patent recycles hydrogen for reuse in fuel cells, while the competitor patent converts methane into electricity in a fuel cell.
tu_ours: The system recycles hydrogen-rich exhaust back to the anode inlet, expanding the utilization range to over 10% to 30% and allowing for both external and internal reforming.
tu_competitor: Converts hydrogen-rich methane from the first separator stream into electricity, reducing carbon dioxide emissions and utilizing the produced electricity in various applications.

overall_reason: While the competitor patent addresses a pressing environmental concern by reducing carbon dioxide emissions, our patent offers opportunities to generate revenue through improved energy production and fuel cell efficiency. Both patents show promise in their respective fields.
